reasoning: The critique targets a meaningful pillar of the essay’s case for “no easy eutopia”: the Section 2 fragility/story that many seemingly-utopian futures still plausibly miss most value because of overlooked single flaws, modeled as (roughly) independent dimensions. If robust institutions and moral-epistemic alignment are part of what makes the ‘common-sense utopia’ plausible, then many listed failure modes may be endogenous (less independent and less likely), which would widen the target and weaken the argument that mostly-great futures are rare by default. However, the critique does not seriously engage the essay’s more technical Section 3 claim that most plausible value functions are intrinsically ‘fussy’ (e.g., linear/unbounded or bounded-with-separate-aggregation arguments), so even if it landed fully it would not collapse the whole position. Strength is moderate because it’s largely a promissory gap-pointing objection: it identifies a missing institutional/stability story and a possible overstep from ‘could’ to ‘likely,’ but does not demonstrate that the relevant failure modes are in fact strongly suppressed or that the product/fragility framing can’t accommodate correlated risks. Most claims in the critique are plausible and largely accurate (the essay doesn’t deeply model institutional endogeneity/dependence), though it somewhat overstates the extent of a ‘could→likely’ shift. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Institutions enabling common-sense utopia would also prevent the listed moral failures
